title: GE CT7-2E1 Turboshaft Clears Half-Million Hours on Leonardo AW149/189 Fleet
description:
GE Aerospace announced on Tuesday that its CT7-2E1 turboshaft engine has accumulated more than 500,000 flight hours in service.
The accumulated flight time indicates steady utilization of the Leonardo airframes in varied operating environments, ranging from maritime conditions to hot-and-high altitude zones.
GE Aerospace confirmed that the CT7-2E1 has previously powered AW149 demonstration flights using SAF at international airshows, demonstrating the hardware’s compatibility with current lower-carbon fuel initiatives.
Elissa Lee, executive director for commercial turboshaft engines at GE Aerospace, noted that the half-million-hour milestone reflects the engine’s role in supporting critical missions for operators worldwide.
As the global fleet of AW149 and AW189 helicopters continues to expand, the CT7-2E1 remains a central component of GE’s commercial rotorcraft portfolio.
text:
GE Aerospace announced on Tuesday that its CT7-2E1 turboshaft engine has accumulated more than 500,000 flight hours in service. This specific engine variant serves as the powerplant for Leonardo’s AW149 and AW189 helicopter fleets, which are currently utilized globally for offshore transport, passenger transit, and search-and-rescue operations.

The CT7-2E1 is a derivative of the established CT7/T700 engine family. While the broader engine family has logged a combined total of over 100 million flight hours across all military and commercial variants, the 2E1 is specifically optimized for the “super medium” helicopter class. The accumulated flight time indicates steady utilization of the Leonardo airframes in varied operating environments, ranging from maritime conditions to hot-and-high altitude zones.

According to the manufacturer, the CT7-2E1 architecture was designed to balance long-range performance with efficiency. While retaining the core design of the T700, this variant incorporates several modern upgrades intended to reduce weight and fuel burn. Key technical features include:

FADEC Integration: A Full Authority Digital Engine Control system for automated engine management.

Material Upgrades: Usage of advanced materials specifically within the turbine section to handle higher thermal loads.

Operational Efficiency: The design focuses on lowering maintenance costs and fuel consumption relative to peer engines in its weight class.

In addition to standard operations, the engine is qualified to operate on approved Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF) blends. GE Aerospace confirmed that the CT7-2E1 has previously powered AW149 demonstration flights using SAF at international airshows, demonstrating the hardware’s compatibility with current lower-carbon fuel initiatives.

Elissa Lee, executive director for commercial turboshaft engines at GE Aerospace, noted that the half-million-hour milestone reflects the engine’s role in supporting critical missions for operators worldwide. As the global fleet of AW149 and AW189 helicopters continues to expand, the CT7-2E1 remains a central component of GE’s commercial rotorcraft portfolio.

title: DevvStream and partners plan integrated platform to grow US SAF supply
description:
DevvStream, Southern Energy Renewables (Southern), and XCF Global have signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding (MoU) to examine the joint development of an integrated low-carbon fuels platform.
This would complement Southern Energy Renewables’ previously announced biomass-based “Gen 2” SAF gasification plant.
DevvStream chairman Carl Stanton said: “Integrating environmental assets directly into the fuel value chain is essential to accelerating SAF deployment.
Projections for 2050 suggest the global SAF market could surpass $250bn.
DevvStream is anticipated to oversee the creation, validation, and commercialisation of environmental assets tied to the platform’s potential low-carbon fuels.
text:
DevvStream, Southern Energy Renewables (Southern), and XCF Global have signed a non-binding memorandum of understanding (MoU) to examine the joint development of an integrated low-carbon fuels platform.

The proposed collaboration aims to boost the availability of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in the US, expand production capacity, and incorporate environmental-attribute monetisation into a single customer solution.

The companies will evaluate the feasibility of building a “Gen 1” SAF facility in Louisiana using hydroprocessed esters and fatty acids (HEFA). This would complement Southern Energy Renewables’ previously announced biomass-based “Gen 2” SAF gasification plant.

This evaluation is part of ongoing negotiations towards a binding agreement that could see the creation of a commercial platform allowing customers to access fuel, logistics, and environmental attributes through one integrated offering.

DevvStream chairman Carl Stanton said: “Integrating environmental assets directly into the fuel value chain is essential to accelerating SAF deployment.

“This collaboration has the potential to bring together three distinct strengths – XCF’s production expertise, Southern’s developing advanced biomass platform, and DevvStream’s environmental-asset monetisation capabilities – to help improve project economics while giving airlines confidence in the integrity of their SAF purchases.”

According to the parties, the US market for SAF is projected to reach nearly $7bn by the end of this decade, with global demand forecasted to surpass 5.5 billion gallons and a total market value exceeding $25bn.

Projections for 2050 suggest the global SAF market could surpass $250bn.

The collaboration is intended to support this expected sector growth by increasing long-term supply across various production pathways and advancing the commercialisation and transparency of environmental attributes.

Environmental-attribute integration is expected to play a significant role in the potential collaboration. DevvStream is anticipated to oversee the creation, validation, and commercialisation of environmental assets tied to the platform’s potential low-carbon fuels.

These assets may include compliance and voluntary carbon credits, CORSIA units, renewable energy certificates, digital measurement, reporting, verification (MRV) tools, and tokenised tracking systems.

The companies also intend to jointly assess solutions for helping customers capture, verify, and monetise attributes such as low-carbon fuel standard (LCFS) credits, renewable identification numbers (RINs), and incentives under regulations such as 45Z/45Q.

Further evaluation will cover lifecycle analysis methodologies and carbon-intensity optimisation systems designed to improve project economics and uphold standards in SAF development.

Southern Energy Renewables CEO Jay Patel said: “We believe partnering with XCF and DevvStream would strengthen our ability to scale a multi-pathway SAF strategy grounded in real production capacity and real climate benefit.”

According to statements from the three companies, the MoU indicates an intention to pursue opportunities in sustainable aviation fuel and related low-carbon fuels.

However, all specific transactions or projects remain subject to due diligence, negotiation of final agreements, internal approvals, and any necessary regulatory clearance.

The MoU does not obligate any party to advance with any particular transaction or project at this stage.

XCF Global CEO Chris Cooper said: “This collaboration has the potential to create the foundation for a first-of-its-kind, fully integrated low-carbon fuels platform, linking production, logistics, and environmental-attribute systems into a seamless value chain.”

title: Swiss WorldCargo and Kuehne+Nagel team up to promote more sustainable air transportation
description:
SWISS, together with its airfreight division Swiss WorldCargo, and logistics provider Kuehne+Nagel have announced a strategic partnership aimed at accelerating more sustainable air transportation, with a strong focus on the development and commercialisation of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).
SWISS, together with its airfreight division Swiss WorldCargo, and Kuehne+Nagel are to embark on a partnership to promote more sustainable air transportation.
Swiss International Air Lines (SWISS), which is Switzerland’s premium air carrier, and Kuehne+Nagel, which is one of the world’s leading logistics service providers, are to deepen their strategic partnership to make air transportation more sustainable.
SWISS, its Swiss WorldCargo airfreight division and Kuehne+Nagel will be jointly supporting the scaling up of this fuel technology.
Partnerships promote SAF development “Sustainable aviation fuels are a key element in our endeavors to make air transportation more sustainable,” stresses SWISS CEO Jens Fehlinger.
text:
SWISS, together with its airfreight division Swiss WorldCargo, and logistics provider Kuehne+Nagel have announced a strategic partnership aimed at accelerating more sustainable air transportation, with a strong focus on the development and commercialisation of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).

As part of the agreement, SWISS will procure at least 200 tonnes of Synhelion SAF per year, reselling a portion to Kuehne+Nagel.

From 2027, Kuehne+Nagel will use Synhelion’s SAF for its airfreight shipments with Swiss WorldCargo over a five-year period, enabling customers to continuedly reduce the carbon footprint of their air cargo transport.

SWISS, together with its airfreight division Swiss WorldCargo, and Kuehne+Nagel are to embark on a partnership to promote more sustainable air transportation. As leading players in their fields, the airline and the logistics concern both support the development and commercialisation of the synthetic aviation fuels manufactured by the Swiss-based Synhelion clean-tech company. One key pillar in this support is the two partners’ long-term commitment to purchase such fuels, which gives Synhelion a sound planning foundation to scale up its synthetic fuel production.

Swiss International Air Lines (SWISS), which is Switzerland’s premium air carrier, and Kuehne+Nagel, which is one of the world’s leading logistics service providers, are to deepen their strategic partnership to make air transportation more sustainable. The partners have signed a Memorandum of Understanding under which they will join forces on various sustainability projects, with a particular focus on new technologies that will bring greater efficiency and sustainability to the transportation sector.

At the heart of the collaboration is the partners’ shared commitment to the sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) which is being developed by Synhelion, the Swiss-based clean-tech pioneer. SWISS, its Swiss WorldCargo airfreight division and Kuehne+Nagel will be jointly supporting the scaling up of this fuel technology. A first milestone has already been achieved here in the partners’ long-term undertaking to procure SAF, which gives fuel manufacturers such as Synhelion the planning foundation they need to scale up their SAF production and further develop their technologies.

Through their use of SAF, SWISS and Kuehne+Nagel will also be making a direct contribution to bringing greater sustainability to the transportation sector. SWISS will procure at least 200 tonnes of Synhelion SAF a year under their new commitment and resell a portion thereof to Kuehne+Nagel.

Partnerships promote SAF development

“Sustainable aviation fuels are a key element in our endeavors to make air transportation more sustainable,” stresses SWISS CEO Jens Fehlinger. “These fuels are still expensive and in short supply, however, which is why we need strong partners to help further their development. We’re delighted that, together with Kuehne+Nagel, we can now initiate the first commercial supplies of Synhelion’s synthetic fuel. This is a major step forward, and a clear confirmation of the active role that SWISS aims to play in this vital area.” .

Under the new commitment, Kuehne+Nagel will use Synhelion’s SAF for its airfreight transports with Swiss WorldCargo for a five-year period from 2027 onwards. In doing so, Kuehne+Nagel will continue its consistent endeavors to help decarbonize the logistics sector, and will also enable its airfreight customers to sustainably reduce their own carbon footprint.

“To meet the aviation industry’s climate targets, we must scale the production of synthetic SAF. At Kuehne+Nagel, we are taking the lead by partnering with SWISS and Synhelion to accelerate these technologies, making them economically viable,” explains Yngve Ruud, Member of the Management Board responsible for Air Logistics. “With it, we can offer our customers the opportunity to reduce their environmental footprint with this innovative technology.”

SWISS continues to pursue a range of measures to reduce the carbon dioxide produced through its flight operations. Along with investments in advanced and fuel-efficient aircraft, sustainable aviation fuels are a key lever in lowering the air transport industry’s carbon emissions. SWISS has been working for many years now with the Lufthansa Group, further partners and its customers to promote the development of such fuels and the scaling up of their production.

title: Europe Aircraft MRO Market Size & Share, 2033
authors: Market Data Forecast, Market Data Forecast ltd
description:
Europe Aircraft MRO Market Size The europe aircraft MRO market size was valued at USD 21.29 billion in 2024 and is anticipated to reach USD 22.34 billion in 2025 from USD 33.92 billion by 2033, growing at a CAGR of 5.36% during the forecast period from 2025 to 2033.
REGIONAL ANALYSIS Germany Aircraft MRO Market Analysis Germany held the leading position in the European aircraft MRO market by accounting for 22.8% of regional activity in 2024.
France Aircraft MRO Market Analysis France captured a promising share of the European aircraft MRO market in 2024.
United Kingdom Aircraft MRO Market Analysis The United Kingdom is anticipated to command a prominent share of the European aircraft MRO market over the forecast period due to its legacy infrastructure, post‑Brexit specialization, and global MRO exports.
Spain Aircraft MRO Market Analysis Spain is expected to exhibit a prominent CAGR in the European aircraft MRO market during the forecast period due to the low‑cost carrier concentration, sunny climate for aircraft storage, and emerging defense partnerships.
text:
Europe Aircraft MRO Market Size

The europe aircraft MRO market size was valued at USD 21.29 billion in 2024 and is anticipated to reach USD 22.34 billion in 2025 from USD 33.92 billion by 2033, growing at a CAGR of 5.36% during the forecast period from 2025 to 2033.

Aircraft maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) is a critical backbone of the continent’s aviation ecosystem ensuring airworthiness operational continuity and regulatory compliance across commercial business and defense fleets. Unlike transactional service sectors aircraft MRO is governed by stringent oversight from the European Union Aviation Safety Agency which mandates recurring inspections component replacements and airframe checks based on flight hours and calendar intervals. According to Eurocontrol, European airlines operated a combined fleet exceeding 3,200 commercial aircraft in 2024, which is reflecting a 12% increase from pre‑pandemic levels and amplifying scheduled maintenance demand. Furthermore, the International Air Transport Association (IATA) reports that the average age of narrow‑body aircraft in Western Europe reached 11.4 years in 2024, elevating the need for structural inspections and system retrofits. The region hosts over 180 EASA Part 145 certified MRO facilities, with major hubs in Germany, France, the United Kingdom, and Spain, leveraging engineering expertise and OEM partnerships. Beyond commercial aviation, Europe’s defense sector maintains over 1,600 fixed‑wing military aircraft, as documented by the European Defence Agency (EDA), necessitating specialized depot‑level maintenance. This intricate interplay of regulatory rigor, fleet dynamics, and technological evolution defines the contemporary European aircraft MRO landscape, as it adapts to sustainability mandates and digital transformation.

MARKET DRIVERS

Aging Commercial Fleet Intensifies Structural and System Overhaul Requirements

The progressive aging of Europe’s commercial aircraft fleet has emerged as a primary driver of MRO demand due to mandatory airframe inspections component fatigue assessments and avionics modernization cycles, which is majorly driving the European aircraft MRO market growth. As per IATA (2024), the average age of narrow body aircraft operated by European carriers reached 11.4 years while wide body fleets averaged 13.7 years, which is signalling entry into high maintenance phases. Aircraft exceeding 10 years require comprehensive D checks every 6–10 years involving complete disassembly corrosion treatment and structural reinforcement. Lufthansa Technik reported conducting 42 heavy maintenance checks in 2023 alone on Airbus A320ceo and Boeing 737 Classic variants all exceeding 12 years of service. According to EASA, repetitive eddy current inspections on wing spars and fuselage lap joints are mandated after 30,000 flight cycles, a threshold increasingly met by legacy fleets. Replacement of obsolete components such as hydraulic actuators and analogue flight displays further compounds workload. As per Cirium (2024), 68% of European narrow bodies are projected to surpass the 12-year mark by 2027. This demographic pressure ensures sustained demand for deep maintenance regardless of short-term traffic fluctuations.

Regulatory Mandates for Avionics Modernization and Emissions Compliance Accelerate Retrofit Demand

European aviation authorities have enacted progressive regulatory frameworks compelling airlines to upgrade aircraft systems for safety communication and environmental performance, thereby fuelling MRO activity and the regional market expansion. According to the European Commission, all aircraft operating in EU airspace must be equipped with Performance Based Navigation and Controller Pilot Data Link Communication capabilities by 2026. This mandate has triggered a wave of avionics retrofits with over 1,400 European registered aircraft undergoing cockpit upgrades in 2023 as per Eurocontrol. Simultaneously the EU Emissions Trading System now fully integrates aviation requiring precise fuel monitoring and data reporting which necessitates installation of advanced fuel flow sensors and flight data recorders. Airbus estimates that 75% of its in service A320 fleet in Europe requires supplemental data acquisition units to comply. Additionally, noise abatement regulations around major airports such as Heathrow and Frankfurt enforce Stage IV noise compliance pushing operators to retrofit hush kits or replace engines. Rolls Royce reported servicing 210 Trent 700 engines in 2024 for noise and emissions enhancements under these rules. These overlapping regulatory imperatives transform MRO from reactive upkeep into a strategic compliance function.

MARKET RESTRAINTS

Persistent Shortage of Certified Aviation Technicians Constrains Capacity Utilization

The Europe aircraft MRO market faces a critical workforce bottleneck due to an acute shortage of licensed aviation maintenance engineers which directly limits shop capacity and turnaround efficiency. According to EASA, over 12,000 new technician certifications are needed annually across the EU to meet current demand yet training institutions produce fewer than 8,000 qualified graduates each year. This gap has widened since 2022 as experienced personnel retired in record numbers with the German Aerospace Industries Association estimating that 35% of its maintenance workforce is over 55 years old. Airlines such as Air France and easyJet have reported MRO slot delays of up to 21 days in 2024 due to staffing shortages at third party facilities. The issue is exacerbated by uneven geographic distribution with Eastern European MRO centers lacking sufficient certified personnel despite available infrastructure. EASA’s strict certification requirements under Part 66 prohibit task delegation to non-licensed personnel for critical inspections further tightening bottlenecks. While virtual reality training and modular certification programs are emerging, the pipeline remains insufficient to support projected fleet growth. This human capital deficit represents a structural ceiling on MRO throughput regardless of capital investment.

Volatility in Aircraft on Ground Periods Disrupts Maintenance Scheduling and Resource Allocation

Unpredictable aircraft utilization patterns driven by operational disruptions and ad hoc route changes have significantly destabilized MRO planning across Europe, which is further impeding the regional market growth. According to the European Cockpit Association (2024), over 28% of short haul flights experienced last minute cancellations or aircraft swaps due to crew shortages and air traffic control constraints. Such volatility forces airlines to defer scheduled maintenance leading to compressed heavy check windows and cascading delays. Lufthansa Technik disclosed that 17% of its planned C checks in Q1 2024 were rescheduled due to unplanned aircraft grounding from technical faults or crew unavailability. This unpredictability complicates inventory management for rotable components and reduces workforce productivity as technicians shift between tasks. Moreover, MRO contracts increasingly include strict turnaround time penalties with non-compliance fees averaging €45,000 per delayed day as per Oliver Wyman industry benchmarks. Facilities operating at 90% capacity cannot absorb these shocks without overtime or subcontracting both of which inflate costs. Until airlines achieve stable flying schedules through improved crew planning and airspace modernization MRO providers will contend with inefficient resource deployment.

MARKET OPPORTUNITIES

Expansion of Digital Twin and Predictive Maintenance Platforms Creates High Value Service Offerings

The integration of digital twin technology and data driven predictive maintenance is unlocking new revenue streams and operational efficiencies for European aircraft MRO market. By creating virtual replicas of aircraft systems fed by real time sensor data from engines APUs and landing gear MRO firms can forecast component failures before they occur. As per Airbus (2024), nearly 900 of its aircraft in European service now transmit live health data through the Skywise platform enabling predictive interventions. Lufthansa Technik’s AVIATAR system processed over 2.3 billion data points in 2024 to optimize component life and reduce unscheduled removals by 18%. This shift from fixed interval to condition-based maintenance extends asset life and minimizes aircraft on ground time. European regulators including EASA have endorsed these models by updating maintenance approval procedures to accept data driven deferrals. Furthermore, digital twins facilitate virtual troubleshooting allowing engineers to simulate repairs before physical work begins cutting workshop time by up to 30% as demonstrated in trials by Satair. Airlines such as Finnair have signed multi-year digital MRO contracts valuing data analytics on par with traditional labor. This transformation positions MRO providers as integrated data partners rather than reactive service vendors.

Growth in Sustainable Aviation Fuel Compatibility Testing Drives Specialized Engine MRO Demand

The accelerating adoption of Sustainable Aviation Fuel across Europe is generating novel MRO requirements centred on engine compatibility certification and material degradation analysis, which is another promising opportunity for the European aircraft MRO market. The European Commission mandates that 6% of all aviation fuel supplied in the EU must be sustainable by 2030 under the ReFuelEU Aviation initiative. Airlines are blending up to 50% SAF in current operations. However, prolonged exposure to certain bio derived fuel components can accelerate seal wear and deposit formation in high pressure turbine sections. Rolls Royce has conducted over 200 engine teardowns since 2022 specifically to assess SAF induced wear with findings integrated into revised maintenance protocols. In 2024 Safran and Air France launched a joint program to monitor CFM56 engines on SAF rich routes with enhanced borescope inspections every 500 flight hours. EASA has issued new service bulletins requiring fuel system material verification for aircraft operating above 30% SAF blends. This regulatory and operational shift compels MRO providers to develop specialized inspection checklists trained personnel and material compatibility databases. As SAF usage expands from niche demonstrations to mainstream operations these tailored engine MRO services will become standard across European maintenance networks.

MARKET CHALLENGES

Fragmented Regulatory Oversight Across Non-EU European States Complicates Cross Border MRO Certification

The absence of harmonized aviation maintenance regulations in non-EU European countries creates significant compliance complexity for pan regional MRO providers, which is a major challenge to the European market growth. While EASA Part 145 certification is recognized across the European Union nations such as Serbia Ukraine and Moldova maintain independent airworthiness authorities with divergent approval processes. According to the European Business Aviation Association, operators in the Western Balkans face an average of 45 additional days to validate MRO work performed in EU facilities due to bilateral agreement delays. This fragmentation forces MRO companies to maintain duplicate documentation systems and pursue country specific approvals inflating administrative costs by an estimated 12% as reported by the European Regions Airline Association. Moreover, components repaired in an EASA certified shop may require re inspection before installation on aircraft registered in non-aligned states disrupting just in time logistics. During the 2024 Balkan airspace recovery following regional disruptions several carriers reported aircraft grounded for over 3 weeks awaiting paperwork validation. Until the European Common Aviation Area fully integrates oversight standards this jurisdictional patchwork will impede seamless MRO service delivery across the continent.

Rising Cybersecurity Vulnerabilities in Connected MRO Ecosystems Threaten Operational Integrity

The digitalization of aircraft maintenance systems has introduced significant cybersecurity risks that threaten data integrity workshop safety and regulatory compliance across Europe, which is further challenging the aircraft MRO market growth in Europe. Modern MRO operations rely on interconnected platforms for technical logbooks component tracking and remote diagnostics yet 63% of European MRO providers reported at least one cyber incident in 2024 according to ENISA. Attack vectors include compromised electronic flight bags falsified service records and malware injected through third party software updates. In one 2023 case a major European MRO facility had to suspend all work for 72 hours after ransomware encrypted its component traceability database delaying over 30 aircraft releases. EASA has since issued cybersecurity guidelines for maintenance organizations but implementation remains voluntary and uneven. The integration of OEM proprietary systems such as Boeing’s AnalytX and Airbus’s Airspace further fragments security protocols. Without standardized encryption access controls and incident response frameworks the industry remains exposed to disruptions that could cascade through the aviation supply chain. This emerging threat dimension necessitates dedicated cyber resilience investments beyond traditional workshop safety paradigms.

REPORT COVERAGE

REPORT METRIC

DETAILS

Market Size Available

2024 to 2033

Base Year

2024

Forecast Period

2025 to 2033

Segments Analysed

By MRO Type, Aircraft Type, End-use, Service Provider Type and region

Various Analyses Covered

Global, Regional & Country Level Analysis, Segment-Level Analysis, Drivers, Restraints, Opportunities, Challenges; PESTLE Analysis; Porter's Five Forces Analysis, Competitive Landscape, Analyst Overview of Investment Opportunities

Regions Analysed

United Kingdom, France, Spain, Germany, Italy, Russia, Sweden, Denmark, Switzerland, the Netherlands, Turkey, and the Czech Republic.

Key Market Players

Lufthansa Technik, Safran Aircraft Engines, Airbus Services, AFI KLM Engineering & Maintenance, SR Technics, MTU Maintenance, Rolls-Royce plc, Sabena technics, SIA Engineering Company, and Turkish Technic.

SEGMENTAL ANALYSIS

By MRO Type Insights

The engine overhaul segment accounted for 37.7% of the European aircraft MRO market share in 2024 and emerged as the most dominating segment in this regional market. The dominance of engine overhaul segment in this regional market is attributed to the high cost, complexity, and regulatory stringency associated with turbine engine maintenance. Aircraft engines account for over 30% of total airframe value and are subject to the most rigorous inspection protocols under EASA Part 21 and OEM service bulletins. Each high‑bypass turbofan requires a full overhaul every 15,000–25,000 flight hours involving disassembly, non‑destructive testing, blade replacement, and performance restoration. In 2023 Rolls‑Royce performed 410 engine shop visits in Europe for its Trent family, according to its annual operations review. Similarly, Safran’s MRO network in France handled over 500 CFM56 and LEAP engine overhauls driven by the aging narrow‑body fleet. The cost of a single wide‑body engine overhaul ranges from €2.5–4 million, which is making it the single largest MRO line item.

The component repair and overhaul segment is the fastest expanding MRO segment in Europe and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 4.4% over the forecast period owing to the proliferation of avionics and electrical systems in modern aircraft. Next‑generation aircraft such as the Airbus A350 and Boeing 787 integrate over 500 line‑replaceable units per airframe ranging from flight control computers to environmental sensors. In 2024 European MRO facilities processed over 1.2 million avionics units, as per the European Organisation for Civil Aviation Equipment. The shift toward fly‑by‑wire architectures has increased dependency on servo actuators and data concentrators, which exhibit higher failure rates in humid or high‑vibration environments. With the average cost of a single flight display repair exceeding €18,000, component MRO has become a high‑margin revenue stream fuelled by system complexity rather than airframe age.

By Aircraft Type Insights

The commercial aviation segment commanded for the largest share of the European aircraft MRO market in 2024. The growth of commercial aviation segment in this regional market is driven by the continent’s dense network of passenger and cargo carriers operating under strict airworthiness regimes. European commercial airlines operate intensive flight schedules, with Ryanair averaging 9.4 block hours per aircraft daily in 2024 according to OAG Aviation Worldwide. This utilization triggers frequent line maintenance checks every 300–500 flight hours and heavy checks every 18–24 months. In 2023 European carriers conducted over 9.8 million commercial flights, generating over 45,000 scheduled heavy maintenance events as documented by IATA.

The military aircraft MRO segment is predicted to experience a CAGR of 4.12% over the forecast period in this regional market owing to the European defense investment surge. European NATO members increased defense spending by 11.3% in 2024, which is totalling €380 billion, as reported by the European Defence Agency. Germany allocated €2.1 billion in 2024 to extend its Tornado fleet until 2030, while Sweden’s Gripen C upgrades included new radar cooling systems and composite skin repairs.

By End User Insights

The commercial passenger airlines segment led the market by accounting for the major share of the European aircraft MRO market in 2024 owing to their role as the primary demand engine. Following pandemic‑induced storage, over 1,200 aircraft were reactivated in Europe between 2022 and 2024, requiring extensive corrosion treatment, system recalibration, and airworthiness validation. As per EASA, each reactivated aircraft incurred an average of €320,000 in MRO costs, with heavy checks comprising 60% of expenses. This catch‑up cycle generated €2.1 billion in incremental MRO revenue in 2023 alone, as estimated by Oliver Wyman.

The cargo operators segment is anticipated to grow at a CAGR of 5.5% over the forecast period in this regional market due to the accelerated freighter conversion programs. The demand for rapid parcel delivery has spurred conversion of retired passenger aircraft into freighters, with over 85 Boeing 737‑800 and Airbus A321P2F conversions delivered to European cargo operators in 2023 as per IBA Insight. Companies like Elbe Flugzeugwerke in Germany performed 22 A321 conversions in 2024 alone for DHL and UPS. The European parcel market grew by 9.4% in 2024 according to PostEurop, ensuring sustained conversion and maintenance demand.

REGIONAL ANALYSIS

Germany Aircraft MRO Market Analysis

Germany held the leading position in the European aircraft MRO market by accounting for 22.8% of regional activity in 2024. The growth of Germany in the European market is driven by its integrated OEM capabilities, dense airline networks, and defense industrial strength. According to Lufthansa Technik, its Hamburg facility performs more than 300 heavy maintenance checks annually, servicing Lufthansa Group aircraft and third‑party carriers from over 40 countries. As per Airbus Defence, the Manching military MRO center maintains more than 200 Eurofighter and Tornado aircraft for the Luftwaffe and allied air forces. According to Germany’s Federal Ministry of Defence, €1.8 billion was allocated in 2024 to extend the Tornado fleet requiring structural and avionics overhauls. As per MTU Aero Engines, the company operates 5 shop visit lines for Pratt & Whitney, GE, and Rolls‑Royce engines. Germany’s dual commercial‑defense footprint, supported by a highly skilled engineering workforce and EASA Part 145 density, ensures unrivaled MRO depth. Additionally, the nation’s central location enables rapid ferry flights from across Europe, further consolidating its hub status.

France Aircraft MRO Market Analysis

France captured a promising share of the European aircraft MRO market in 2024. The OEM integration, national carrier demand, and defense modernization are driving the French market growth. France’s MRO ecosystem is uniquely shaped by its vertically integrated aerospace champions. According to Safran, its Villaroche facility near Paris performs more than 600 engine overhauls annually. As per Dassault Aviation, its Bordeaux Falcon MRO center services about 150 aircraft yearly. According to Air France Industries KLM Engineering & Maintenance, its Paris Charles de Gaulle hangars conducted 180 heavy checks in 2024. As outlined by the Direction Générale de l’Armement, France’s military modernization program includes life extension for 117 Rafale fighters, each requiring 12‑week depot‑level overhauls every 7 years. In 2024, Dassault Aviation signed a 10‑year MRO contract with the French Air Force valued at €900 million. France’s regulatory rigor, high technical standards, and OEM ownership of MRO workflows create a self‑sustaining industrial loop that attracts international operators seeking OEM‑certified work.

United Kingdom Aircraft MRO Market Analysis

The United Kingdom is anticipated to command a prominent share of the European aircraft MRO market over the forecast period due to its legacy infrastructure, post‑Brexit specialization, and global MRO exports. Despite Brexit, the UK remains a premier MRO destination due to its concentration of EASA and UK CAA dual‑approved facilities. According to British Airways Engineering, its Heathrow base performed 140 heavy maintenance checks in 2024. As per STS Aviation Services, its line maintenance network expanded to 32 European airports. According to Rolls‑Royce, the Derby engine overhaul center completed more than 500 Trent engine shop visits in 2024. As per AJW Group, the company manages component inventory for about 150 airlines worldwide. In 2024, the UK Department for Transport launched the Future Flight Challenge, allocating £125 million to develop MRO protocols for hybrid‑electric aircraft. The UK’s strategic pivot toward high‑value niche services, including aircraft storage, reactivation, and engine leasing, ensures continued relevance despite regulatory divergence. Its time zone advantage also facilitates coordination with North American and Middle Eastern operators.

Spain Aircraft MRO Market Analysis

Spain is expected to exhibit a prominent CAGR in the European aircraft MRO market during the forecast period due to the low‑cost carrier concentration, sunny climate for aircraft storage, and emerging defense partnerships. Spain’s MRO growth is fueled by its role as the operational base for Europe’s largest low‑cost carriers. According to Ryanair, the airline operates more than 450 aircraft from Spanish bases requiring extensive line maintenance. As per Iberia Maintenance, its Madrid Barajas facility conducted 110 heavy checks in 2024, primarily for A320 and A350 fleets. According to Teruel Airport, more than 220 aircraft were stored at its facility in 2024 due to favorable climate conditions. Companies like TAP MRO Atlantic use this infrastructure for cost‑effective reactivation programs. As per Airbus and Indra, a joint maintenance simulation center was established in Getafe under the FCAS fighter program. In 2024, the Spanish Air Force extended the C‑295 transport fleet life by 15 years requiring structural and avionics overhauls. This blend of commercial cost advantage and strategic defense investment secures Spain’s rising MRO profile.

Italy Aircraft MRO Market Analysis

Italy is predicted to witness a notable CAGR in the European aircraft MRO market during the forecast period owing to the business aviation leadership, military fleet sustainment, and Mediterranean logistics positioning. Italy is Europe’s foremost business jet MRO hub, with facilities in Milan, Rome, and Olbia servicing more than 500 private and corporate aircraft annually. According to Leonardo, its Pisa component repair center supports AW139 and AW189 helicopter fleets used by 30 countries. As per the Italian Air Force, the service maintains about 180 fixed‑wing aircraft, including F‑35s and Tornados, requiring specialized depot‑level maintenance at Cameri Air Base in partnership with Lockheed Martin. In 2024, Leonardo signed a 15‑year MRO agreement with the Italian Ministry of Defence covering 90 aircraft and valued at €1.2 billion. Italy’s geographic position also makes it a preferred maintenance stop for Middle Eastern and African operators transiting Europe. Post‑pandemic Mediterranean tourism recovery has further increased ad hoc MRO demand at secondary airports. With strong OEM capabilities and strategic location, Italy sustains a high‑value niche MRO presence distinct from mass commercial models.

COMPETITIVE LANDSCAPE

Competition in the Europe aircraft MRO market is defined by a dual structure comprising OEM affiliated providers and independent third party specialists each vying for dominance through technological differentiation and service integration. OEM linked entities such as Lufthansa Technik Safran and Airbus Defence leverage design authority access proprietary tooling and factory trained engineers to maintain exclusivity on complex heavy maintenance and engine overhauls. In contrast independent players compete on turnaround speed cost efficiency and geographic proximity particularly in line maintenance and component repair. The market is further segmented by aircraft type with commercial MRO dominated by scale players handling narrow body fleets while military MRO is concentrated among defense integrators with sovereign security clearances. Regulatory oversight from EASA creates high entry barriers ensuring quality but also limiting new entrants. Intensifying pressure from airlines for cost transparency has spurred bundled service contracts and digital performance guarantees. Meanwhile the rise of predictive maintenance platforms is redefining value from labor execution to data insight. This dynamic fosters a competitive landscape where innovation sustainability and operational agility outweigh traditional capacity metrics.

KEY MARKET PLAYERS

Some of the companies that are playing a dominating role in the Europe Aircraft MRO Market include

Lufthansa Technik

Safran Aircraft Engines

Airbus Services

AFI KLM Engineering & Maintenanc

SR Technics

MTU Maintenance

Rolls-Royce plc

Sabena technics

SIA Engineering Company

Turkish Technic

Top Players in the Market

Lufthansa Technik

Lufthansa Technik is a globally recognized leader in aircraft maintenance repair and overhaul headquartered in Germany with operations spanning four continents. The company provides comprehensive MRO services for commercial regional and VIP aircraft including airframe heavy maintenance engine shop visits and digital fleet management solutions. Lufthansa Technik contributes significantly to the global MRO ecosystem through its proprietary AVIATAR platform which enables predictive maintenance using real time aircraft data. In 2024 the company expanded its engine services portfolio by launching a dedicated facility in Budapest for LEAP and PW1000G engine overhauls. It also deepened partnerships with European low cost carriers through power by the hour agreements enhancing its integrated service offerings and reinforcing its position as a technology driven MRO provider.

Safran Aircraft Engines

Safran Aircraft Engines is a French multinational and a cornerstone of Europe’s aerospace maintenance infrastructure specializing in turbine engine overhaul and support. As part of the Safran Group it delivers MRO services for CFM International LEAP and M88 military engines to operators worldwide. The company plays a pivotal role in global engine sustainment through its global support network and OEM authorized repair capabilities. In recent developments Safran inaugurated a digital twin enabled maintenance center near Paris in early 2024 focused on AI driven diagnostics for LEAP engines. It also extended its long term service agreements with major European airlines incorporating sustainable aviation fuel compatibility checks into routine overhaul protocols thereby aligning MRO processes with decarbonization mandates.

Airbus Defence and Space Maintenance Services

Airbus Defence and Space Maintenance Services represents the military and government segment of Airbus’s broader MRO strategy with major facilities in Germany Spain and France. The organization provides depot level maintenance for Eurofighter Typhoon A400M C295 and NH90 platforms serving over 25 national air forces. Its global contribution lies in enabling sovereign maintenance capabilities through technology transfer and training programs in partner nations. In 2024 Airbus Defence activated a new structural repair line in Manching Germany dedicated to extending the service life of Tornado and Eurofighter fleets under European defense modernization initiatives. The company also integrated blockchain based traceability for spare parts to comply with NATO supply chain security standards strengthening its position in high security military MRO.

Top Strategies Used by the Key Market Participants

Key players in the Europe aircraft MRO market pursue vertical integration by combining OEM design authority with certified maintenance execution to ensure technical exclusivity and customer lock in. They invest heavily in digital transformation deploying predictive analytics digital twins and AI driven diagnostics to shift from time based to condition based maintenance models. Strategic expansion of engine and component repair capabilities for next generation platforms such as LEAP and PW1000G secures long term revenue streams. Companies establish power by the hour and total care contracts bundling labor parts and logistics into fixed cost agreements enhancing customer retention. Geographic diversification through service center networks in Eastern Europe and the Mediterranean improves turnaround efficiency for low cost carriers. Partnerships with sustainable aviation fuel producers enable MRO providers to offer compatibility testing and material degradation monitoring as value added services. Workforce development via certified training academies addresses technician shortages while ensuring regulatory compliance. These strategies collectively reinforce competitiveness in a capital intensive and regulation heavy environment.

title: Shell signs agreement to purchase SAF from Green Sky Capital - Oils & Fats International
description:
The agreement would help provide commercial certainty for investors to move forward with plans to build Egypt’s first commercial-scale SAF plant, Shell said in a 5 December LinkedIn post.
“By securing 100% of the plant’s output, Shell is strengthening its global supply network for low-carbon fuels and helping aviation meet decarbonisation targets,” said Geoff Mansfield, vice president, low carbon fuels, at Shell Trading.
As of July 2025, Shell had delivered SAF to more than 80 locations in 18 countries and, in 2024, became one of the world’s leading SAF traders and suppliers with close to 20% of total sales in Europe and North America, the company said.
Shell said the offtake agreement reflected the company’s strategy to scale up SAF availability worldwide and support airlines in meeting regulatory mandates and voluntary commitments.
Green Sky Capital is developing renewable fuel projects across the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region, starting with the planned facility in Egypt.
text:
The agreement would help provide commercial certainty for investors to move forward with plans to build Egypt’s first commercial-scale SAF plant, Shell said in a 5 December LinkedIn post.

Located in Egypt’s Suez Canal Economic Zone, the facility was scheduled to become operational by the end of 2027 and would produce up to 145,000 tonnes/year of SAF, as well as bio-naphtha and bio-propane, the company said.

“By securing 100% of the plant’s output, Shell is strengthening its global supply network for low-carbon fuels and helping aviation meet decarbonisation targets,” said Geoff Mansfield, vice president, low carbon fuels, at Shell Trading.

As of July 2025, Shell had delivered SAF to more than 80 locations in 18 countries and, in 2024, became one of the world’s leading SAF traders and suppliers with close to 20% of total sales in Europe and North America, the company said.

Shell said the offtake agreement reflected the company’s strategy to scale up SAF availability worldwide and support airlines in meeting regulatory mandates and voluntary commitments.

Green Sky Capital is developing renewable fuel projects across the Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region, starting with the planned facility in Egypt.

title: Egypt Attracts $200M Qatari Investment for Sustainable Aviation Fuel
description:
Egypt has signed a contract with Qatari holding company Al Mana for a first-phase investment of $200 million to produce sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from used cooking oil in the Suez Canal Economic Zone (SCZone) at Ain Sokhna.
The agreement marks the first industrial investment by a Qatari company in the SCZone.
Al Mana has secured a long-term offtake agreement with Shell Global Aviation, under which Shell will purchase the facility’s entire output.
Deliveries of SAF are scheduled to begin by late 2027, following the completion of construction and commissioning.
The facility will produce fuel that meets international aviation fuel specifications and is expected to support export growth from the SCZone, while expanding Egypt’s industrial capacity in energy and advanced fuel production.
text:
Egypt has signed a contract with Qatari holding company Al Mana for a first-phase investment of $200 million to produce sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) from used cooking oil in the Suez Canal Economic Zone (SCZone) at Ain Sokhna.

The project will be developed over three phases on a 100,000 m² site in the Integrated Sokhna Zone on Egypt’s Red Sea coast. The first phase is expected to have an annual production capacity of approximately 200,000 tons, comprising SAF produced via hydrotreated vegetable oil (HVO) technology, alongside co-products BioPropane and BioNaphtha. All outputs will be derived from the refining of used cooking oils. The agreement marks the first industrial investment by a Qatari company in the SCZone.

Al Mana has secured a long-term offtake agreement with Shell Global Aviation, under which Shell will purchase the facility’s entire output. Deliveries of SAF are scheduled to begin by late 2027, following the completion of construction and commissioning.

The facility will produce fuel that meets international aviation fuel specifications and is expected to support export growth from the SCZone, while expanding Egypt’s industrial capacity in energy and advanced fuel production.

title: SAF Coalition Members Welcome Introduction of H.R. 6518, The Securing America's Fuels Act
description:
Washington, D.C. – Last week, Representatives Mike Flood (R-NE), Sharice Davids (D-KS), Tracey Mann (R-KS), and Troy Carter (D-LA) introduced the Securing America’s Fuels (SAF) Act, H.R.
6518, bipartisan legislation that would restore the full value of the tax credit and extend the entire 45Z tax credit through 2033.
The Securing America’s Fuels Act reinstates the higher $1.75 credit rate for sustainable aviation fuel and extends the credit to 2033, two critical components needed to accelerate investment and secure new demand for American-grown biofuels.
The ACA strongly supports bipartisan efforts that ensure agriculture remains the backbone of America’s energy future.” —Tom Buis, ACA, CEO Boeing: “Boeing welcomes the introduction of The Securing America’s Fuels Act.
And now it’s time to lead a new industry – sustainable aviation fuel.
text:
Washington, D.C. – Last week, Representatives Mike Flood (R-NE), Sharice Davids (D-KS), Tracey Mann (R-KS), and Troy Carter (D-LA) introduced the Securing America’s Fuels (SAF) Act, H.R. 6518, bipartisan legislation that would restore the full value of the tax credit and extend the entire 45Z tax credit through 2033. Members of the SAF Coalition issued the following statements of support.

Airlines for America:

“U.S. airlines are grateful to Representatives Flood, Davids, Carter, and Mann for introducing legislation that would restore and extend the full 45Z tax credit. This will stimulate private sector investment in SAF while also bolstering American energy dominance. This credit is a win-win for both the aviation and agriculture industries, supporting U.S. job growth across the country.”

American Carbon Alliance:

The American Carbon Alliance (ACA) applauds Reps. Mike Flood (NE-01), Sharice Davids (KS-03), Troy Carter (LA-02), and Tracey Mann (KS-01) for championing bipartisan legislation to strengthen Section 45Z and provide long-term certainty for clean fuel producers. The Securing America’s Fuels Act reinstates the higher $1.75 credit rate for sustainable aviation fuel and extends the credit to 2033, two critical components needed to accelerate investment and secure new demand for American-grown biofuels.

“Restoring the full 45Z credit and extending it to 2033 gives farmers and producers the certainty they’ve been missing, and it opens the door to new aviation markets. That means more demand, stronger prices, and real economic growth in rural America. The ACA strongly supports bipartisan efforts that ensure agriculture remains the backbone of America’s energy future.”

—Tom Buis, ACA, CEO

Boeing:

“Boeing welcomes the introduction of The Securing America’s Fuels Act. This bipartisan legislation aligns with our strategy to enable responsible growth in aviation, where increasing the supply of SAF complements other measures like designing and building a new generation of fuel-efficient airplanes.”

Darling:

“America has always led the way. And now it’s time to lead a new industry – sustainable aviation fuel. This is about jobs, innovation and securing our energy future. If we’re not at the table, others will write the rules. We’re ready to show what America can deliver – and smart policy will make it happen.”

—Shelby Neal, Vice President of Renewables and Energy Policy, Darling Ingredients

Delta:

“Delta applauds Reps. Flood (R-NE), Davids (D-KS), Mann (R-KS) and Carter (D-LA) for their leadership in introducing the Securing America’s Fuels Act, which will ensure 45Z reaches its full potential and provides the critical investment certainty necessary to bring additional SAF production facilities online to meet our industry’s unprecedented demand for cost-competitive, homegrown fuels.”

—Cherie Wilson, Vice President, Government Affairs – Sustainability, Delta Air Lines

GBTA:

“GBTA strongly supports the passage of the SAF Act. This bill will improve economic growth and lower costs for consumers and business travelers over time. We appreciate your leadership in advancing practical, pro-growth climate and energy solutions for aviation.”

—Suzanne Neufang, CEO, GBTA

Gevo:

“Domestic demand for jet fuel continues to rise, and policy can help support investment in new facilities needed to produce cost-competitive alcohol-to-jet synthetic aviation fuel (SAF) to meet this demand. Gevo thanks U.S. Reps. Sharice Davids (KS), Mike Flood (NE), Troy Carter (LA), and Tracey Mann (KS), for prioritizing SAF by introducing the Securing America’s Fuels Act to help accelerate solutions that increase American energy production – and grow rural and farm economies. The Securing America’s Fuels Act reflects ongoing bipartisan support for building a durable future for domestic jet fuel production that leverages the strength of U.S. agriculture by restoring the full value of the SAF credit and extending the 45Z credit through 2033.”

—Lindsay Fitzgerald, Chief Public Affairs Officer, Gevo

Twelve:

“Turning American feedstocks into American-made SAF is how we strengthen our energy independence and fuel U.S. innovation. Restoring the full SAF credit keeps this critical industry growing here at home.”

—Nicholas Flanders, Co-Founder and CEO, Twelve

United:

“United is grateful for the leadership of Representatives Mike Flood, Sharice Davids, Tracey Mann, and Troy Carter in introducing the “Securing America’s Fuels (SAF) Act”, which will help to ensure that the U.S. remains the world’s leading producer of SAF and other clean fuels, while also creating a huge market opportunity for U.S. farmers and feedstock producers. Extending the credit’s duration and guaranteeing its full value are pivotal policy actions that would accelerate domestic SAF production, strengthen U.S. energy and climate leadership, and reinforce America’s position as the world’s most competitive producer of cleaner, lower-carbon jet fuel.”

—Tom Michels, Director of Government Affairs, United Airlines

title: Egypt–China ties underpin logistics, infrastructure & trade cooperation
description:
Foreign Minister Badr Abdelatty welcomed the pace of bilateral engagement during a telephone call with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, noting that sustained political coordination has created a framework for deeper economic and investment cooperation between the two countries.
The foreign minister pointed to the role of Chinese companies in major infrastructure projects in Egypt, including the Light Rail Transit project and the Central Business District in the New Administrative Capital.
These projects are seen as strengthening urban transport capacity, connectivity and logistics efficiency, alongside cooperation in renewable energy and desalination.
The logistics role of Ain Sokhna has also been expanded through new industrial investments linked directly to port operations.
The discussions come as Egypt continues to position economic zones and transport corridors as platforms for foreign investment tied to manufacturing, logistics and trade flows, supported by large-scale infrastructure development.
text:
Egypt’s government has linked the rapid development of Egypt–China relations to expanding cooperation in infrastructure, transport and trade-related sectors that support logistics and supply chains, according to statements made during high-level diplomatic exchanges on December 16, 2025.

Foreign Minister Badr Abdelatty welcomed the pace of bilateral engagement during a telephone call with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi, noting that sustained political coordination has created a framework for deeper economic and investment cooperation between the two countries.

According to Foreign Ministry spokesman Tamim Khallaf, Abdelatty said Egypt is seeking to convene the fifth round of the ministerial-level Strategic Dialogue and the joint committee meeting to advance cooperation across multiple domains, as both sides prepare to mark 70 years of diplomatic relations next year.

The foreign minister pointed to the role of Chinese companies in major infrastructure projects in Egypt, including the Light Rail Transit project and the Central Business District in the New Administrative Capital. These projects are seen as strengthening urban transport capacity, connectivity and logistics efficiency, alongside cooperation in renewable energy and desalination.

Ain Sokhna’s logistics positioning has also been reinforced by recent developments at the port, where Deputy Prime Minister for Industrial Development and Minister of Industry and Transport Kamel El-Wazir received a Guinness World Records certificate recognising Ain Sokhna as the deepest man-made port basin constructed on land, with a depth of 19 metres. The port’s development forms part of a national plan to enhance Egypt’s role in international trade and position Sokhna as a logistics and transit hub on the Red Sea, supporting large vessels, higher cargo volumes and port-centric supply chains.

The logistics role of Ain Sokhna has also been expanded through new industrial investments linked directly to port operations. Earlier this month, Prime Minister Dr Mostafa Madbouly witnessed the signing of a contract for a sustainable aviation fuel production project by Qatari Al-Mana Holding Company in the Sokhna Integrated Zone of the Suez Canal Economic Zone. The project marks the first Qatari industrial investment within the Suez Canal economy and involves the establishment of SAf Fly Limited, a dedicated production entity located across both the industrial zone and the port area, integrating manufacturing and maritime logistics functions.

With an investment of $200 million, the project is being developed on a total area of 100,000 square metres, including 30,000 square metres inside Ain Sokhna port, enabling direct access to export infrastructure. The facility is designed to produce 200,000 tonnes annually of sustainable aviation fuel, bio-propane and bio-naphtha, derived from used edible oils. Al-Mana Holding has signed a long-term supply agreement with Shell to purchase the full output, with fuel deliveries scheduled to begin by the end of 2027, reinforcing Sokhna’s role in global energy and aviation fuel supply chains.

Abdelatty also highlighted investment opportunities linked to Egypt’s strategy to localise industry and transfer technology, with an emphasis on attracting Chinese investment in artificial intelligence and digitalisation, areas that support modern logistics, industrial automation and supply chain management.

The discussions come as Egypt continues to position economic zones and transport corridors as platforms for foreign investment tied to manufacturing, logistics and trade flows, supported by large-scale infrastructure development.

The call also covered coordination in multilateral forums and regional developments, including Gaza and Sudan, with both sides stressing continued consultation and cooperation as part of the broader strategic partnership.

title: Long-term synthetic SAF offtake agreed to support aviation sustainability - FreshPlaza
description:
A central element of the agreement is collaboration around sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) produced by Synhelion, a Swiss cleantech company developing synthetic fuels made using solar energy.
© Kuehne+Nagel Under the agreement, Kuehne+Nagel, together with SWISS and its air freight division Swiss WorldCargo, will participate in a long-term SAF offtake framework designed to align fuel supply with expected demand.
The aim is to contribute to more stable market conditions for emerging synthetic aviation fuels and to support further technological development.
According to Kuehne+Nagel, scaling the production of synthetic SAF is necessary to support the aviation sector's longer-term climate objectives.
Synhelion's technology focuses on producing synthetic fuels using concentrated solar energy to create drop-in fuels compatible with existing aircraft and infrastructure.
text:
Kuehne+Nagel and Swiss International Air Lines (SWISS) have signed a Memorandum of Understanding to expand their cooperation on sustainability initiatives in aviation, with a focus on improving efficiency and reducing environmental impact.

A central element of the agreement is collaboration around sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) produced by Synhelion, a Swiss cleantech company developing synthetic fuels made using solar energy. The partners have agreed on a long-term offtake arrangement intended to support the scaling of Synhelion's technology and provide greater planning certainty for future production.

© Kuehne+Nagel

Under the agreement, Kuehne+Nagel, together with SWISS and its air freight division Swiss WorldCargo, will participate in a long-term SAF offtake framework designed to align fuel supply with expected demand. The aim is to contribute to more stable market conditions for emerging synthetic aviation fuels and to support further technological development.

From 2027, Kuehne+Nagel plans to purchase Synhelion-produced SAF from SWISS for a period of five years, to be used for cargo shipments handled by Swiss WorldCargo. The SAF volumes will be applied to reduce the CO₂ footprint associated with these air freight movements, offering customers an option to lower emissions linked to their shipments.

According to Kuehne+Nagel, scaling the production of synthetic SAF is necessary to support the aviation sector's longer-term climate objectives. The company stated that partnerships with airlines and fuel producers are required to move new technologies beyond pilot scale and toward broader commercial use.

SWISS noted that sustainable aviation fuels are expected to play an important role in reducing emissions from air transport, but availability remains limited and costs remain high. The airline described the agreement as a step toward bringing new SAF solutions into commercial operation and increasing experience with alternative fuels in day-to-day operations.

Synhelion's technology focuses on producing synthetic fuels using concentrated solar energy to create drop-in fuels compatible with existing aircraft and infrastructure. The long-term offtake agreement is intended to support further investment and capacity expansion as the technology moves toward industrial-scale deployment.

The partners stated that the cooperation is aimed at contributing to the development of the SAF market rather than addressing aviation emissions on its own, highlighting the need for broader industry participation to achieve a meaningful impact.

title: EcoCeres Earns Prestigious RSB ICAO CORSIA Certification, Underscoring Global ...
description:
Hong Kong – 16 December, 2025 – EcoCeres Inc., a leading pure-play renewable fuels producer, announced that it has attained certification under the RSB ICAO CORSIA scheme for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), a globally recognised standard aligned with the International Civil Aviation Organization’s Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA).
The certification goes further than other CORSIA-eligible schemes to ensure robust social safeguards and biodiversity protection, while confirming that EcoCeres’ SAF meets rigorous requirements for sustainability, greenhouse gas (GHG) reduction, and traceability.
It is globally recognised as the best-in-class certification for SAF products by leading civil society organisations, including the World Wide Fund for Nature and the International Union for Conservation of Nature.
“Receiving RSB ICAO CORSIA certification is a major milestone for EcoCeres and a strong endorsement of our commitment to producing SAF that delivers measurable climate benefits and advances the circular economy,” said Matti Lievonen, CEO of EcoCeres.
By combining waste based feedstocks, advanced production technologies and independent verification under RSB ICAO CORSIA, EcoCeres is well positioned to help customers reduce lifecycle emissions from aviation while strengthening the credibility of their decarbonisation claims.
text:
Hong Kong – 16 December, 2025 – EcoCeres Inc., a leading pure-play renewable fuels producer, announced that it has attained certification under the RSB ICAO CORSIA scheme for Sustainable Aviation Fuel (SAF), a globally recognised standard aligned with the International Civil Aviation Organization’s Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA). The certification goes further than other CORSIA-eligible schemes to ensure robust social safeguards and biodiversity protection, while confirming that EcoCeres’ SAF meets rigorous requirements for sustainability, greenhouse gas (GHG) reduction, and traceability.

The ICAO CORSIA certification, developed by the Roundtable on Sustainable Biomaterials (RSB), is among the most robust frameworks globally for verifying SAF against stringent environmental and social criteria, including significant lifecycle GHG reductions, protection of high-carbon and high-biodiversity areas, and strong safeguards for workers and local communities. It is globally recognised as the best-in-class certification for SAF products by leading civil society organisations, including the World Wide Fund for Nature and the International Union for Conservation of Nature.

“Receiving RSB ICAO CORSIA certification is a major milestone for EcoCeres and a strong endorsement of our commitment to producing SAF that delivers measurable climate benefits and advances the circular economy,” said Matti Lievonen, CEO of EcoCeres. “This recognition not only validates the robustness of our feedstock sourcing and production processes but also gives our airline partners confidence that our fuels

meet the highest international standards for sustainability and emissions performance.”

The certification supports EcoCeres’ strategy to expand its presence in international SAF markets and to partner with airlines and fuel suppliers that must comply with CORSIA obligations and other emerging SAF mandates. By combining waste based feedstocks, advanced production technologies and independent verification under RSB ICAO CORSIA, EcoCeres is well positioned to help customers reduce lifecycle emissions from aviation while strengthening the credibility of their decarbonisation claims.

title: India sets target of 5% biofuel blend by 2030 on international flights
description:
The targets would initially apply to international flights departing from India, the 1 December report said.
As a member of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), India is obligated to comply with the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) – a global market-based mechanism aimed at reducing emissions from international flights.
The scheme applies only to international flights.
India had joined ICAO’s Assistance, Capacity-building and Training for Sustainable Aviation Fuels (ACT-SAF) programme, which supported member states in adopting cleaner aviation fuels and reducing carbon emissions from international aviation, Mohol added.
The Union Civil Aviation Ministry said the push for SAF and readiness for CORSIA were in line with India’s wider climate commitments, including its Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) under the Paris Agreement.
text:
To enable a gradual shift toward green aviation, the government had approved SAF blending targets of 1% by 2027, 2% by 2028 and 5% by 2030, Murlidhar Mohol, Minister of State for Civil Aviation, told Parliament in response to a question.

The targets would initially apply to international flights departing from India, the 1 December report said.

Acknowledging the challenges of higher production costs and limited SAF feedstock availability, public sector oil marketing companies were “actively engaged” in meeting the targets, the minister said.

As a member of the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO), India is obligated to comply with the Carbon Offsetting and Reduction Scheme for International Aviation (CORSIA) – a global market-based mechanism aimed at reducing emissions from international flights.

Under the scheme, airlines will be required to offset emissions above 2019 levels starting from 2027. The scheme applies only to international flights.

India had joined ICAO’s Assistance, Capacity-building and Training for Sustainable Aviation Fuels (ACT-SAF) programme, which supported member states in adopting cleaner aviation fuels and reducing carbon emissions from international aviation, Mohol added.

The Union Civil Aviation Ministry said the push for SAF and readiness for CORSIA were in line with India’s wider climate commitments, including its Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) under the Paris Agreement.

title: Metafuels Awards McDermott FEED Contract for First Commercial e-SAF Plant in Rotterdam
description:
December 17, 2025 [Global-eFuels]- Metafuels, the Swiss aviation technology company, has awarded McDermott a front-end engineering and design (FEED) contract for its Turbe project, Europe’s first commercial synthetic sustainable aviation fuel (e-SAF) facility at the Evos terminal in the Port of Rotterdam.
The Turbe plant will deploy Metafuels’ proprietary methanol-to-jet technology, aerobrew, producing drop-in e-SAF compatible with existing aircraft and infrastructure.
The FEED phase, which precedes the final investment decision (FID), includes basic engineering, technical specification optimization, and cost estimation.
This project marks a key step in scaling Metafuels’ technology from demonstration to industrial deployment.
The facility will serve as a blueprint for large-scale e-SAF production, aligned with EU mandates including ReFuelEU Aviation and CORSIA, supporting Europe’s aviation decarbonization targets through 2030 and beyond.
text:
December 17, 2025 [Global-eFuels]- Metafuels, the Swiss aviation technology company, has awarded McDermott a front-end engineering and design (FEED) contract for its Turbe project, Europe’s first commercial synthetic sustainable aviation fuel (e-SAF) facility at the Evos terminal in the Port of Rotterdam.

The Turbe plant will deploy Metafuels’ proprietary methanol-to-jet technology, aerobrew, producing drop-in e-SAF compatible with existing aircraft and infrastructure. The FEED phase, which precedes the final investment decision (FID), includes basic engineering, technical specification optimization, and cost estimation.

This project marks a key step in scaling Metafuels’ technology from demonstration to industrial deployment. Earlier in 2025, Metafuels successfully installed its 50 liters-per-day methanol-to-jet demonstration plant at Switzerland’s Paul Scherrer Institute and expanded its European presence through Metafuels Nederland B.V.

Turbe is designed for high efficiency and cost leadership, converting e-methanol to e-SAF at yields that reduce lifecycle carbon emissions by up to 90 percent compared to conventional kerosene. The facility will serve as a blueprint for large-scale e-SAF production, aligned with EU mandates including ReFuelEU Aviation and CORSIA, supporting Europe’s aviation decarbonization targets through 2030 and beyond.

title: I Squared Capital To Acquire Zenith Energy Terminal | citybiz
description:
I Squared Capital, a leading independent global infrastructure investor, today announced that its Energy Transition Infrastructure Fund has entered into a definitive agreement to acquire 100% of the Zenith Energy Terminal in Portland, Oregon, a major Renewable Diesel and Sustainable Aviation Fuel logistics hub on the U.S. West Coast.
The terminal is essential to helping Portland and the State of Oregon meet their clean fuel policy goals.
Based in Portland’s Northwest industrial district, the terminal includes 1.7 million barrels of storage capacity and multimodal connectivity via rail, marine, truck and pipeline.
As part of an agreement with city officials, the terminal is on track to convert 100% of its fossil fuel storage to renewable fuel by October 2027.
It is a critical component of Portland’s existing energy infrastructure and is currently the only facility in Oregon with SAF storage.
text:
I Squared Capital, a leading independent global infrastructure investor, today announced that its Energy Transition Infrastructure Fund has entered into a definitive agreement to acquire 100% of the Zenith Energy Terminal in Portland, Oregon, a major Renewable Diesel and Sustainable Aviation Fuel logistics hub on the U.S. West Coast. The terminal is essential to helping Portland and the State of Oregon meet their clean fuel policy goals.

Based in Portland’s Northwest industrial district, the terminal includes 1.7 million barrels of storage capacity and multimodal connectivity via rail, marine, truck and pipeline. As part of an agreement with city officials, the terminal is on track to convert 100% of its fossil fuel storage to renewable fuel by October 2027. It is a critical component of Portland’s existing energy infrastructure and is currently the only facility in Oregon with SAF storage. The terminal was the origin of PDX’s first-ever SAF delivery in September of this year.

Commenting on the acquisition, Gautam Bhandari, I Squared Capital Global Chief Investment Officer & Managing Partner, said: “We see significant opportunity for the Portland facility and look forward to deepening our commitment to the region by moving the new headquarters to Portland and hiring a local management team. We believe the terminal is uniquely positioned to become one of the West Coast’s leading renewable fuel hubs, supported by strong structural demand for low-carbon fuels and a broad shift toward sustainable transportation solutions.”

Damian Darragh, Fund Partner, I Squared Energy Transition Infrastructure Fund said: “At I Squared we are committed to investing in local leadership, transparent operations, world-class safety standards, strong partnerships with Portland and Oregon stakeholders, and supporting a steady transition from fossil fuels to a cleaner future.”

As an SFDR Article 9 fund, the ISQ Energy Transition Infrastructure Fund is targeting projects that materially contribute to the energy transition. With a mandate to back renewable fuels and clean-energy infrastructure, this investment ensures that the Portland terminal continues to be aligned with the long-term decarbonization and resilience goals of the city of Portland and the state of Oregon, as well as furthering the Fund’s ambition to deliver a more sustainable future.

The transaction is subject to customary regulatory approvals and closing conditions. Financial terms were not disclosed.

title: Kuehne+Nagel and SWISS deepen partnership to scale sustainable aviation fuel
description:
Global logistics firm Kuehne+Nagel and Swiss International Air Lines (SWISS) have expanded their strategic partnership to speed up the use of cleaner aviation solutions, with a strong emphasis on increasing the availability of sustainable aviation fuel.
A key element of the agreement is a long-term commitment to purchase sustainable aviation fuel, which is expected to give Synhelion the certainty needed to move its technology to industrial-scale production.
Under the arrangement, Kuehne+Nagel, SWISS and Swiss WorldCargo will work together to support the adoption of Synhelion’s fuel.
From 2027, Kuehne+Nagel plans to buy Synhelion’s sustainable aviation fuel from SWISS for a period of five years and apply it to its air cargo shipments transported by Swiss WorldCargo.
SWISS said cooperation across the industry is crucial to address the limited availability and high cost of sustainable aviation fuel.
text:
Global logistics firm Kuehne+Nagel and Swiss International Air Lines (SWISS) have expanded their strategic partnership to speed up the use of cleaner aviation solutions, with a strong emphasis on increasing the availability of sustainable aviation fuel. The cooperation has been formalised through a memorandum of understanding and aims to support the market entry of solar-based synthetic fuels developed by Swiss clean energy company Synhelion, reports STAT Trade Times.

A key element of the agreement is a long-term commitment to purchase sustainable aviation fuel, which is expected to give Synhelion the certainty needed to move its technology to industrial-scale production. Synhelion produces renewable synthetic fuels by using solar energy to create liquid hydrocarbons, including solar jet fuel, which can significantly cut emissions over their life cycle without requiring changes to existing aircraft or airport infrastructure.

Under the arrangement, Kuehne+Nagel, SWISS and Swiss WorldCargo will work together to support the adoption of Synhelion’s fuel. By signalling reliable demand, the partners aim to help attract further investment and enable production to scale up. From 2027, Kuehne+Nagel plans to buy Synhelion’s sustainable aviation fuel from SWISS for a period of five years and apply it to its air cargo shipments transported by Swiss WorldCargo. This will support Kuehne+Nagel’s wider efforts to reduce emissions and allow customers to lower the carbon footprint of their air freight.

Kuehne+Nagel said expanding the supply of synthetic sustainable aviation fuel is essential for the aviation sector to meet its climate goals, and partnerships such as this are needed to bring new technologies to commercial viability. The company added that the agreement will help customers take part in reducing emissions through the use of alternative fuels.

SWISS said cooperation across the industry is crucial to address the limited availability and high cost of sustainable aviation fuel. The airline noted that working with logistics partners on long-term fuel purchases is an important step toward making cleaner fuels more widely available and supporting the first commercial use of Synhelion’s product.

The partnership highlights a broader trend in the aviation and logistics sectors, where long-term fuel purchase agreements are increasingly being used to reduce risks for new technologies and help move them from pilot projects to full commercial deployment.
